question.title: In jaxb, can I distinguish between elements that have the same type but different names?
question.body:
I am trying to process XMLs in Scala which have an awkward XSD where different element names are mapped to the same type.

    <xsd:element name="NVAnfangF" type="NVAnfang"/>
    <xsd:element name="NVAnfangS" type="NVAnfang"/>
    <xsd:element name="NVEndeF" type="NVEnde"/>
    <xsd:element name="NVEndeS" type="NVEnde"/>

So, in certain contexts, I can have either an <NVAnfangF .../> or an <NVAnfangS .../> and they correspond to very similar, but not identical objects in reality.

Earlier, I tried generating Scala classes using scalaxb, and it levels the distinction between these two tags, giving me only a case class NVAnfang.

Do I have any chance of automatically generating bindings for this XML specification that can distinguish NVAnfangF and NVAnfangS with standard Scala or Java libraries?

Does for example jaxb allow me to configure it such that the element name is picked up? Or am I forced to write my own code generator that takes F vs. S into account?

question_comments.body: Yes, it's a Choice, and the owner class is something that has a Key ("NVAnfangF") and a value (a NVAnfang instance), and that's how to access the difference.

From the XSD, they are the same type. Makes sense that this is a single case class NVAnfang definition in Scala. I would expect that you have some kind of parent class with two attributes nvafangf and ...s of the type though. Can you share the complete XSD, is this a choice?

I haven't been able to get it to work properly, but following github.com/eed3si9n/scalaxb/issues/549 and scalaxb.org/narrower-choice this is actually included in ScalaXB's design, so maybe I just need to figure out how to use it.
